label: Studs Terkel talks with Arthur C. Clarke (1959)
content:
Studs : Across the microphone is the... Mr Arthur C. Clarke a man described by a good number of critics - highly respected critics - as the colossus of science fiction. It'd be hard to numerate the various facets of Mr Clarke's... Mr Clarke's interests. So many. He's the past president of the British Interplanetary Society, lectures, Skin Diver, Globetrotter, Explorer but perhaps over and above that observer of the... of the human comedy that is. Mr Clarke I feel very guilty during this interview to be because I know very little of science fiction of your work and this is a sign of my particular benighted that's because I know that you are highly respected man in this field sir. Now what is the British Interplanetary Society which you a past president?

Arthur : Well the British Interplanetary Society which was started 1933 was an organization that tried to convince people there was something in this space nonsense, because no one took us seriously until about... well after the Second World War when the V2 started arriving and still more after the satellites and Sputniks. It was a scientific society and it still is, it's quite a large one now, about three or four thousand members. It is in fact the largest organization in the world devoted specifically to space problems.

Studs : So this group which was thought a scientifically avant garde-ish has now become accepted as just a .

Arthur : Indeed almost old fashioned.

Studs : Old fashioned! You touch... I understand from reading some of the reviews very rapidly here and I know that I've got to atone for this very soon for my own sake, read your works. Childhood's End is considered one of your finest science fiction books.

Arthur : Yes it is generally and it has had an extraordinary wide acceptance often among people who say almost proudly: "Well I've never read any other science fiction but I like... I think Childhood's End is quite a remarkable book." This happens a lot and incidentally last year I sold it to Hollywood I don't know what they're going to make it.

Studs : When the question arises: you the writer of science fiction, you yourself are a physicist are you not sir?

Arthur : Well I took my degree at King's College London in physics and mathematics I've never done any scientific research but I did become a scientific editor of a leading physics journal and I did for a couple of years, until I found that my writing was earning more than my editing and so I gave up the editing.

Studs : Now in the matter of... Before we touch upon the number of books you've written various ones like The City and The Stars and Earth Light as well as a Childhood's End and some of the non-fiction works and the... the book The Deep Range. But what about the writer of science fiction today? Is it true that he can... he can make more comment, more pungent comment about our society in the world than say a writer of conventional fiction?

Arthur : That's very true and that's one of the attractions of science fiction and in fact it has been for many years if you go... many centuries. If you look back in the history of literature you see a lot of writers like Defoe, Dean Swift used media which we would now call Science Fiction. Gulliver's Travels for example is an ... is an early form of Science Fiction and they were able to poke fun at their societies and satirize conditions: political, religious, moral in a way which was very effective and also is much safer for the writer than if you took an obviously recognizable portrait of his own society and this is happening right now and it has happened all through the last decade. For instance some of the most trenchant criticism of certain trends in American politics in the last few years. I'm thinking of a certain dead senator appeared in some of the science fiction stories which extrapolated these trends and showed what they might lead to.

Studs : And in short this is beyond censorship because a man cannot condemn your writing since you deal with a society that is not here.

Arthur : Exactly. In fact I don't... I don't think there's a single theme which hasn't appeared in Science Fiction. I mean themes which couldn't possibly be touched in main-stream literature have been touched on and examined more or less dispassionately in Science Fiction.

Studs : Well with all this talk today of Man and other planets, man and other spheres and still not having solved so many of the problems of this sphere. The question comes up: Don't your books sometimes become dated that as you speak of some... something that seems so fantastic yet becomes real, suddenly real.

Arthur : That's true but then Science Fiction has two aspects: firstly you might say there's a technological aspect to the story which is mainly concerned with some invention or discovery and its effects on people. Well that's a kind of story can easily become dated. Let me give an example: One of my first novels Prelude to Space was about the launching of the first space-ship to the moon and I wrote that I think in 1947 and I put it about thirty years ahead of that time. Well now since I wrote that story and almost half the things I've described have taken place and there had been ... different changes of emphasis for example I never imagined when I wrote the story that Russia was going to play the leading part in space exploration as she has and is going to do. And certain shifts of technical emphasis. Well these things change and do in a way date a story but the other aspects which might... you might say the philosophical aspects of stories are discussing future they don't necessarily come out of date for instance many of Wells's stories and in many of Verne's stories - there's a lot of ideas in them which are still quite valid now.

Studs : In here then the... the Science Fiction writer something of a prophet is he not.

Arthur : He can be a prophet. Though again I should stress that he doesn't set out to be a prophet but like all writers he should set out to entertain and make people think and sort of stretch their imaginations and sometimes he does prophecy but that is accidental.

Studs : You say he sets out to entertain - at the same time you would not describe science fiction as escape literature.

No on the contrary this is a common canard, which I'd like to refute. If one does refute a canard - people, critics often who've never read any of it. Essays well science fiction is escapist. This is absolute nonsense in fact at the moment I got an editorial of John Campbell's in front of me Campbell is the editor of Astounding Science Fiction which despite its title is about the one of the most literate magazines of fiction going and he says how annoyed he's been of people who call science fiction escape literature because he said it's not and it never has been and in fact he says: "Science Fiction is just about the only non escape literature available to the general public today" and then it goes on to criticize "the soft almost formless, nearly pointless stories found in the mass circulation magazines" are a wonderful retreat from reality and he goes on to say: that Science Fiction is concerned and concerned with real things that are happening right now and their effects on society.

I mean far far closer to us, to our lives than to I think like say a man in the gray flannel suit..?

Arthur : Well that's a kind of reality the kind of escapism is the... is the Private Eye historical novel and you name it they're all over the place that is fantasy .

Studs : Forever Amber type.

Arthur : That is pure fantasy ... yes.

Studs : Fantasy though, you mean allegedly dealing with humans, dealing with cardboards whereas you seemingly dealing with unrealistic.

Quite.

You will come much closer to us.

Arthur : And for this reason as a matter that has been quite a slump in Science Fiction because a lot of people went into it thinking that it was escape and they suddenly found to their horror that isn't in fact. There's a quote from Campbell's editorial again, says: "Probably nothing is so deeply disturbing as to have a nice safe fantasy, wake up, stretch immense muscles, yawn and start looking around, all on its own and not controlled by your imagination anymore." He's referreing to what's happened to atomic power and space travel which a lot of people thought were pleasant fantasies they could play with and suddenly realize these are the most real things in our world.

Studs : Here's a case of a man's imagination suddenly leading to a pavement reality.

Arthur : Yes.

Studs : And what about requisites for Science Fiction writers? You yourself are a scientist sir. You mentioned something earlier we... I brought up the name of Ray Bradbury a noted writer of what I thought was Science Fiction. You called it Fantasy.

Arthur : Well now Ray is a very fine writer but he does not write Science Fiction. He writes a type of Fantasy which is being strongly influenced by Science Fictional themes. He's difficult to define. You might say all good writers are probably difficult to define but he is not on the mainstream of Science Fiction. He's been affected, often negatively affected. In other words he dislikes many of these Science Fiction ideas and his stories are against... are antiscientific in some ways.

Studs : I see you mention something a negative viewpoint there is something here in the review of your book Childhood's End by William Dubois, Dubois the New York Times. He writes of you Arthur Clarke: "He is equally at home in the outer galaxies in the troubled psyche of modern man and if he seems to agree with Norman Cousins that modern man is rather obsolete. His pity for that same homo sapiens never wavers when he rings his curtain down, man as we know him today is as dead as all man's pathetic schemes for self destruction but no one can escape the conviction that the Phoenix just risen from the ashes is destined for higher things. Does this mean sir that you're an optimist?

Arthur : Yes fundamentally I am and I've expressed as in most of my books. Man going out and colonizing, conquering and colonizing space at least the nearer planets of this sun and setting up new societies, new civilizations there which may far exceed anything on this planet and I have stressed the point that what we are seeing now is a new renaissance this is the main theme incidentally of my next book The Challenge of the Spaceship. Deliberately Toynbee in the title which is my collection of my essays not of course from holiday in Harper's and elsewhere discussing the impact of largely the political and social and philosophical and religious impact of space travel on human society. I think it's going to be on the whole overwhelmingly to the good.

Studs : You feel that through man's inventiveness man's advances scientifically that man in a human sense too can sociologically or socially?

Arthur : Yes because it's going to give us a much more accurate perspective. When we can see this earth of ours as it really is a rather small pebble floating among the stars and many of our present tribal squabbles will become as ... appear as ridiculous as they are.

Studs : Tribal squabbles?

Arthur : Yes ... that's all they are now.

Studs : In contrast to the ...to, to what awaits us.

Arthur : In contrast to the cosmos.

Studs : I'm thinking of something else. You speak of the cosmos and I think of big things this is wandering for a moment. Something you mentioned earlier about members of the non-human world you speak of mans... our our treatment of the whale today, the big fish. Now you spoke of the whale becoming. You speak... you speak of the whale farm being something of the future.

Arthur : And we guess so I'm rather... and this may seem a bit of a digression but it's really all part of the same pattern. I got very interested in the sea and so I tend to spend most of my time underwater. I've done two expeditions now, one to the Great Barrier Reef of Australia and another one Ceylon where in fact I now live in Colombo and they're your going to an alien world of meeting strange creatures as we will do out in space, which is probably the reason why I'm interested in it and I got interested in whales partly because of this and partly because I suppose Moby Dick had a greater impact on me than any other novel ever read and I did ... a book called The Deep Range which is about whale ranching whale farming. Which is a definite possibility in the near future and I ... to see a long article in The Wall Street Journal touching on it only yesterday I mean these thing these ideas are getting around. We're still as fast as sea is concerned in these states that primitive man was and he was a hunter before he invented agriculture we go and hunt these creatures. Not only whales but fish. We haven't yet started to farm the sea and this is a matter of desperate necessity as our population increases and these things will be done I believe in the near future. Forms of agriculture on the sea growing crops and conserving breeding and treating the animals fish and whales of the sea as we treat animals on land.

Studs : You mean their food values...

Arthur : Yes but I'm also not only concerned with the food values. As far as whales are concerned these are fascinating beasts. Part of the most... the second or third most intelligent animals on the earth - they're somewhere between the chimpanzee and the dog in their intelligence their cattle of course and they can be certainly controlled like cattle they have a language of their own, we've recorded it and as I say they can communicate by sound and we can definitely herd them if we wish to and ... Well I'm interested in conservant... the conservancy angle too. I mean I like to see these creatures preserved and not just hunted to extinction.

Studs : At the moment the whale you feel is going the way of the buffalo.

Arthur : Well there's a danger of that and there are attempts now to cut down the ... slaughter by international agreement. But.

Studs : There's something else you're touching upon here that intrigues me - the... your attitude toward the whale it's beyond the attitude of man toward beast here. I think this may be connected with your reference or passing reference to Moby Dick being the book that most infl... Is there a moral aspect to it here somewhere that intrigued.

Arthur : Oh yes very much in fact I think I let it get out of control in The Deep Range. Possibly because of the influence of Buddhism on my thinking. I live in a Buddhist community. All my friends and neighbors are Buddhists in Celon and in fact in The Deep Range I did I ended up the book with the whole whale slaughtering campaign being stopped by the Buddhist hierarchy and now you can only look... you can only conserve the whales and not allowed to kill them any more. This is probably a little bit impractical but that's the way I feel about it. I'm, I'm lets say I'm probably a moral vegetarian even though in fact I hate vegetables and eat meat wen I can get it.

Studs : But spiritually your a vegetarian.

Arthur : I'm a spiritual vegetarian.

Studs : As much as Shaw was physically?

Arthur : Yes. Quite. But I love a nice steak, whether it's a whale steak or a cow steak.

Studs : Mr Clarke, your interest is so varied and so many I know there are so many facets of your of your... of your way of thinking we'd like to delve into. Perhaps an all inclusive question - this is not to wind up this conversation I'm just reaching out because I know so little of your writings - I'd like to know more. Your credo as a scientist as a novelist as a writer of science fiction as an adventurer, sociologist too. What about... before we touch that your credo and then perhaps we'll touch upon space travel.

Arthur : Well I suppose Space travel is really part of my credo. I adopt the scientific humanist outlook. I don't... I'm a complete agnostic. I don't have any religious faith and I believe that it's a few thousand years premature to arrive at any religious faiths. We are rather like islanders, somewhere in the middle of an enormous ocean on a little island. We've never been off this island, we don't know anything about the great wide world, what's out there, what other races, what other species are there and it's obviously futile for us to try and speculate about the purpose of the universe, when we don't even know a thing about it so I think all are religious speculation so far, just literaly childish. In fact I have an article in Horizon magazine, this new you know an American heritages come in, in Horizon on the impact of spaceflight on religion and philosophy and in the long run it's going to be pretty overwhelming.

Studs : You say that you think we're a couple of thousand years premature in the matter of...

Arthur : This maybe an underestimate.

Studs : ...of arriving at a fate. An underestimation, your point is... I'm just trying... I'm trying to understand your point, in order for us to have a faith about ourselves and about the universe we know more about the universe itself.

Arthur : Yes but let me put this perhaps in more concrete terms. You see the only real... the only certain knowledge we have of the universe around us has in fact been arrived by scientific methods. I'm using the word science in the widest possible sense. Science after all means knowledge doesn't necessarily mean technology in test tubes and cyclotrons, but it does mean knowledge and in the past we've seen what a overwhelming effect scientific discoveries have had on the philosophical religious ideas. Let me just mention the Copernican revolution which simply shattered the theological framework of the Middle Ages. The Darwinian revolution which had an equally great impact that a greater one because it affected men personally. One hundred years ago in fact more recently than that in Tennessee.

Studs : It's true.

Arthur : And now... and in this century of the Freudian revolution there's others to come and space travel is going to be one of them, particularly when as I think will happen eventually though perhaps not for a long time, we come up against very superior races.

Studs : You you feel that you say superior races, you mean you have no idea of course what form no beings will take.

Arthur : But I mean when you look out at the universe there are a hundred thousand million suns in this galaxy of ours alone and if only say one in ten has got planets, that may mean that to every single person on this earth, there's somewhere with an inhabited world. That's about the number of inhabited worlds in this universe, one for every man woman and child on this earth. Well it seems very unlikely that on many of those there won't be races that will regard us as somewhere back in the stone age.

Studs : I'm curious to this kind of a superior race as you said you mean.

Arthur : Well I mean morally, intellectually, philosophically.

Studs : No wars, that kind of thing.

Arthur : Well a superior race cannot have war because war is a self liquidating activity.

Studs : Well you're a man sir who sees more than let's say a conventional pavement pounder might see here you feel and there will be a revolution as far as religious beliefs are concerned.

Arthur : Yes I think I think in fact eventually that what we call religious beliefs will cease to be held by intelligent men.

Studs : But they will have a faith of a sort.

Arthur : Well yes I mean obvious you have to have a certain faith, I mean you have to have a faith that life is worth living I mean that's a ... in the basics of the way of faith and some people haven't got that nowadays.

Studs : Well I think I think that you, Mr Clarke, express a great deal of faith perhaps what's most important of all, in the human being and in his destiny and it's certainly been a delight for me to have you with a guest on this program for listeners WFMT and I think we should, I think for all of us we should brush up on some of your works: Childhoods End is one of your books, Earth Light is another your novels and the outer side of...

Arthur : The Other Side of the Sky.

Studs : The Other Side of the Sky. Is this fiction too?

Arthur : Yes that was my last collection of short stories. Harcourt Brace are doing all my fiction now and sometime later this year they're putting out a big anthology of over six hundred pages with Childhood's End and Earth Light about twenty short stories and Clifton Fadiman is going to do an introduction to this. I hope it will have quite an effect.

Studs : Perhaps the last paragraph of the review of The New York Times review of Childhood's End might paint an interesting picture of you here: "This review can only hint at the stimulation Mr Clarke's novel offers. Above all it must be emphasized this is not a gloomy book, despite its holocausts. It is true the invaders from outer space managed to steal the big scenes but homo-sapiens fights back to the end with resourcefulness and wit. What's more he rarely allows himself to be upstaged even when he's faced with his own extinction." And perhaps on this note Mr Clark one last word from you. Are we faced with our own extinction?

Arthur : Well obviously we are faced with it but I don't think it is inevitable that we will make the wise choice because everybody is agreed that the choice has to be made and that extinction is a possibility of our generation the first generation of mankind ever had this possibility in front of it. I'm optimistic about the outcome.

Studs : Either to be... either to destroy himself or to be perhaps even more noble than ever is it.

Arthur : Yes.

Studs : So the choice is ours.

Arthur : The choice is ours and it's really a privilege to be born in this age, the most critical in the whole history of mankind.

Studs : A bit discomforting but exciting.

Arthur : Discomforting but exciting I remember the old Chinese proverb: "May you live in interesting times." Well is it rather a Chinese curse: "May you live in interesting times." Well that curse is being visited on us but I don't think it really is a curse. It's a privilege.

Studs : And it could be a blessing too.

Arthur : Could be.

Studs : Mr Clarke thank you very much for being our enlightening guest, very enlightening indeed. Thanks a lot.

Arthur : Thank you. I'm glad to have been here.

media.label: Studs Terkel talks with Arthur C. Clarke (1959)
